1 JOURNAL OF MOLECULAR CATALYSIS ELSEVIER Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 149-167 Physicochemical properties of Ti02-S'02 unmodified and modified with H2S04 and activity for acid catalysis Jong Rack Sohn a,*, Hyang Ja Janga, Man Young Parka, Eun Hee Parka, Sang Eun Parkb eDepartment of Industrial Chemistry, Engineering College, Kyungpook National University, Taegu 702-701, South Korea 'Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, Taejon, 305-606, South Korea Received 4 August 1993; accepted 3 June 1994 Abstract A series of Ti02-Si02 catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation from the mixed solution of titanium tetrachloride and sodium silicate. Some of the sample were modified with 0.5 M HZS04 and used as modified catalysts. The addition of Ti02 to Si02 caused the increase of acidity and acid strength, and the shifts of O-H and Si-O stretching bands of silanol group to lower frequencies in proportion to the Ti02 content. Catalytic activities for 2-propanol dehydration and cumene dealkylation increased in relation to the increase of acidity and the band shifts to lower frequencies. The catalytic activities of modified catalysts were higher than those of unmodified catalysts, and the effect of modification on catalytic activity was higher for 2-propanol dehydration than for cumene dealkylation. The effect of modification on catalytic activity increased with increasing Ti02 content of the catalysts. Actually, 92-Ti02-SiOz/SOQ- had the highest increment in catalytic activity and 10-Ti02Si02/SO;- had the lowest increment for the 2-propanol dehydration. Keywords: Acid catalysts; Modified catalysts; Physicochetnical properties; Silica; Sulphuric acid; Titania 1. Introduction Recently, many kinds of mixed oxides have been reported to show surface acidity. Metal oxide which is inactive or slightly active by itself induces a high catalytic activity by the addition of other oxide. Silica-alumina and silica-zirconia catalysts may be cited as an example of this phenomenon [ 1-7 ] . The activity of 2102-Si02 * Corresponding author. 0304-5102/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. Sohn et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994)149-167 catalyst was directly proportional to the number of acid centers on the surface [ 8 ] . The combination of Ti02 and Si02 generates strong acid sites and a theory for the creation of acidic sites in Ti02-Si02 has been presented [ 9 ] . The properties of these coprecipitated Ti02-Si02 gels have also been reported [ 11-13 ] . Acid catalyzed reaction is correlated with acidity and acid strength. In cumene dealkylation the more acidic the catalysts, the higher catalytic activity they show [ 14,15 ] . On the other hand, tert-butanol dehydration takes place on relatively weaker acid sites, while skeletal isomerization of isobutylene requires exceedingly strong acid sites [ 16 ] . Thus to incorporate more acidity and stronger acid strength, single or binary oxide catalysts are modified with sulfuric acid [ 17-23 ] . The high catalytic activity of catalyst modified with sulfuric acid is attributed to the enhanced acidic property by the inductive effect of S=O bonds of the complex formed by the interaction of oxides with sulfate ion [ 22,24 ] . In this work, the physicochemical properties of a series Ti02-SiO2 catalysts prepared by coprecipitation method was investigated using X-ray diffraction, IR and XPS. The acidic properties of a series of Ti02-Si02 having various molar ratios of Ti02/SiO2 and their relationship to the activities for acid catalysis have been studied. Also the catalytic activities of Ti02-SiO2 modified with HZS04 are compared in detail with those of unmodified catalysts. For this purpose, the 2propanol dehydration and cumene dealkylation were used as test reactions. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst The coprecipitate of Ti (OH) 4-Si (OH) 4 was obtained by adding aqueous ammonia slowly into a mixed aqueous solution of titanium tetrachloride and sodium silicate solution at room temperature with stirring until the pH of the mother liquor reached 8. The ratio of titanium tetrachloride to sodium silicate was varied. The coprecipitate thus obtained was washed thoroughly with distilled water until chloride ions were not detected, and dried at 100 C. The dried coprecipitate was again washed with successive portions of a 5% ammonium nitrate solution and then with hot distilled water to remove sodium ion in the coprecipitate. The sample was powdered below 100 mesh and was used as catalyst after calcination at 350 C for 1.5 h. To obtain the modified catalysts 2 g of each dried precipitate was treated with each 30 ml of 0.5 M sulfuric acid followed by drying the sample in air as described elsewhere [ 22-25 ] . The dried solid powders were used as modified catalysts after calcination at 400 C for 1.5 h. All the catalysts prepared are tabulated in Table 1 together with their surface area. The catalysts are denoted by following a mole percentage of Ti02- That is, 92-Ti02-Si02 represents the catalysts having 92 mol% of Ti02 and 92-TiO2-SiO2/504- represents 92-Ti02-Si02 catalyst modified with 0.5 M H2S04. JA Sohn et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994)149-167 151 2.2. Procedure 2-Propanol dehydration was carried out at 180 C in a pulse microreactor connected to a gas chromatograph. Fresh catalyst in the reactor made of 1 /4 in. stainless steel was pretreated at 400 C for 1 h in the nitrogen atmosphere. Diethylene glycol succinate on Simalite was used as packing material for the gas chromatography and the column temperature was 150 C for analyzing the product. Catalytic activity for 2-propanol dehydration was represented as Amol of propylene converted from 2-propanol per surface area. Cumene dealkylation was carried out at 400 C in the same reactor as above. Packing material for the gas chromatography was Bentone 34 on Chromosorb W and column temperature was 130 C. Catalytic activity for cumene dealkylation was represented as jamol of benzene converted per surface area. Conversions for both reactions were taken as the average of the first to sixth pulse values. The acidity and acid strength of catalyst were measured quantitatively and qualitatively, respectively, using a series of the Hammett indicators. The catalyst in a glass tube was pretreated at 400 C for 1 h and the tube filled with dry nitrogen. For the determination of acid strength of the catalyst the color changes of the indicators were observed by spot test. Acidity was determined by the amount of n-butylamine which was dropped into the catalyst steeped in dry benzene until the color of indicator adsorbed on the catalyst disappeared. The sulfur content remaining on the catalyst after the calcination at 400 C for 1.5 h was determined by a thermal analyzer model PL-STA 1500 HF. The S03 content in the catalysts was estimated to be about 3-5 wt%. The specific surface area was determined by applying the BET method to the adsorption of nitrogen at -196 C. FTIR spectra were recorded using a Mattson model GL 6030E spectrometer. Usually 10 mg of catalyst was mixed with 100 mg of KBr and pressed into a disk (600 kg /cm2). For IR studies of OH stretching region (4000-3500 cm-'), self-supported disks of about 10 mg cm-2 were used. X-ray diffractograms of catalysts were taken by Rigaku model 2125D2 using copper target and nickel filter at 30 kV and 1000 cps. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was performed on Hitachi 507 photoelectron spectrometer equipped with cylindrical mirror analyzer using A1 anode (9 kV, 50 mA). Binding energy values were calculated in reference to the C1S level at 285.0 eV. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Infrared spectra of the catalysts A series of Ti02-Si02 calcined at 400 C was examined by IR absorption in the mid-infrared region, using the KBr disk technique. The spectra of bands around 1200-1100 cm-' due to Si-O skeletal stretching vibrations were sharper with increasing Ti02 content because of the higher degree of order [ 26] , indicating a different structure. The band of Si02 at 974 cm-' is assigned to the Si-O stretching vibration of the silanol group [ 27,28 ] . As shown in Fig. 1, however, the vibration band was affected by Ti4+, consequently shifted to a lower frequency and became broader with increasing Ti02content. This suggests the presence of some interaction between Ti02 and Si02 particles in the Ti02-Si02. This interaction may originate in the formation of Si-O-Ti bond as the following model: H O O -O-Si -0-Ti-0- I A I 0 O The formation of Si-O-Ti bond is also confirmed by XPS data, as will be described below. It seems likely that the shifts of the Si-0 stretching band for the silanol group are responsible for the weakness of the Si-0 bond by withdrawing electrons in the Si-O bond through the interaction between them. Tanabe et al. suggested a similar model in regard to the acidity generation of binary oxides [ 10] . For 87-Ti02-Si02 and pure Ti02. the weak and broad band around 920 cm-' is assigned to the stretching vibration of the Ti-O-Ti bonds [ 31 ] . We also examined the IR spectra of some physically mixed Ti02-Si02 samples, but the shifts of the Si-O stretching band for silanol groups was not observed. Therefore, it is clear that the shift of 974 cm'band mentioned above is not due to overlapping of the Ti-0 band. X-ray diffraction The crystalline structures of catalysts calcined in air at different temperatures for 1.5 h were checked by X-ray diffraction. In the case of a single Ti02, most of Ti02 calcined at 300 C was present as amorphous form to X-ray diffraction together with tiny amount of anatase. However, as shown in Fig. 6, the amount of anatase Ti02 increased remarkably at the calcination temperature of 350 C, indicating that amorphous Ti02 was transformed into anatase form, and then Ti02 was present as anatase form up to 700 C. There was a two phase mixture of the anatase and rutile forms at 800 C and just only rutile format 900 C. For Ti02/S04- similar results were obtained except that the transition temperature from amorphous to anatase was 100 C higher, as compared with pure Ti02- It is assumed that strong bond formation between sulfate ion and Ti02 hinders the transition from amorphous to anatase [ 24,25 ] . Fig. 9 shows the acidity of both series catalysts. The used indicator was dicinnamalacetone of Ho = - 3.0 and acidity was expressed as Ouiv/m2 of used catalyst. Although single component, Si02 showed little acidity, mixing of the two component, Ti02 and Si02 resulted in remarkable increase in acidity. This increase was not caused only by increase in surface area. As shown in Fig. 9, the acidity increases gradually upon the addition of Ti02 to Si02 reaching a maximum at 73-Ti02-Si02. These results are correlated with those of O-H and Si-O band stretching shifts of silanol group to lower frequencies upon the addition of Ti02 to Si02 described above. That is, the more the band shift, the more acidity has the catalyst. Many kinds of combinations of two oxides were reported to generate acid sites on the surface [ 8-10] . The combination of Ti02 and Si02 generated the stronger acid sites and the more acidity as compared with the single components. The mechanism for the generation of acid sites by mixing of two oxides has been proposed by Tanabe et al. [ 9,10] . They explained that the acidity generation is caused by an excess of a negative or positive charge in a model structure of a binary oxide related to the coordination number of a positive element. 160 J.R. Infrared spectroscopic studies of pyridine adsorbed on solid surfaces have made it possible to distinguish between Bronsted and Lewis acid sites [45]. Fig. 10 shows the infrared spectra of pyridine adsorbed on Ti02 and Ti02/504- evacuated at 400 C for 1.5 h. The coordinated pyridine band at 1445 cm-' is found with Ti02. while both the pyridinium ion band at 1541 cm-' and the coordinated pyridine band at 1447 cm-1 are found with Ti02/S04-. It is clear that the new Bronsted acid site which is not present on pure Ti02 is formed by modifying Ti02 with HZS04. Fig. 11 shows the infrared spectra of pyridine adsorbed on 92-Ti02-Si02 and 92-Ti02-Si02/S04- evacuated at 400 C for 1.5 h. Both the absorption band at 1543 cm-t due to Bronsted acid and the band at 1445 cm-' by Lewis acid are found with them, indicating the presence of both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites. These results show that the addition of Ti02 to Si02 produces the new Bronsted acid sites through the interaction between Ti02 and Si02, although pure Ti02 has only Lewis acid sites as described above. Conclusions A series of catalysts, Ti02-Si02 with different compositions and modified with H2S04 were prepared by a coprecipitation method, and the following facts are demonstrated in this work. (1) Modifying Ti02 with H2S04 shifted the transition of Ti02 from amorphous to anatase form to high temperature. (2) The addition Of Si02 to Ti02 delayed the transition from anatase to rutile form. (3) The addition of Ti02 to Si02 resulted in the formation of Si-0-Ti bond, and caused shifts in the O-H and Si-O stretching bands of silanol group to lower frequencies in proportion to the Ti02 content. These band shifts were correlated with both acidity and acid catalytic activity of the Ti02-Si02 catalysts. (4) Modification with H2S04 enhanced the activities of the catalysts remarkably, thus being responsible for the superacidic properties of the modified catalysts. The modification effect on catalytic activity increased with increasing the Ti02 content of catalysts.
